page.title: 02LANDSCAPE OF WEST PENKRIDGE
page.content: The area is mainly flat with a few gentle hills. There are pockets of woodland and one larger wood, Stretton Wood, in the south-west. Most of the fields are devoted to mixed farming, with grassland predominating. The fields are enclosed by high hedges and reached by narrow lanes. There are a number of Dutch barns. Several brooks traverse the area and there are pools of varying sizes. The River Penk is crossed by the Cuttlestone Bridge which dates from the 16th Century. Several of the larger farms - Bickford Grange, Kinvaston Hall - Preston Vale, have roofs and chimneys which show them to be Georgian or earlier.
